fullText:
Democracy Dies in DarknessReview by Naveen KumarNEW YORK — The magnificent wall of sound in the full-company opening number of “Ragtime” is a patriotic metaphor. America’s promise has always rested on uneasy accord among people — in this case, a mix of White, Black and immigrant New Yorkers around 1906 — that threatens at any moment to explode. Harmony is rare enough lately that even in song it can feel like deliverance.

showScoreExcerpt: "Fortunately, the show sounds gloriously lush throughout...So much so that it hardly needs much embellishment at all."

llmScore.reasoning: [ensemble-unanimous] | All 3 models agree: Mixed | Claude: The review acknowledges clear strengths (material, cast, director's vision) but notes significant weaknesses (bold strokes don't always work, narrative pitfalls). The balanced 'succeeds but doesn't always benefit' language indicates a mixed assessment. | GPT-4o: The review acknowledges the success of the material and cast, but also notes shortcomings in the production's approach, leading to a mixed assessment. | Gemini: The review highlights both successes (cast, material) and failures (overly bold direction, reliance on archetypes), resulting in a mixed assessment. The aggregator verdict of 'Flat' supports this classification.

dtliExcerpt: It succeeds on the merits of the material and the powerhouse principal cast reprising their roles. Director Lear DeBessonet, in her first show as artistic director of Lincoln Center Theater, makes some appealing use of the grand canvas, a promising sign for her upcoming tenure. But the production doesn’t always benefit from these bold strokes, which underline the pitfalls of a narrative told through archetypes and melodrama.
